note.p: Thomas Jesse Wharton was attorney general of Mississippi during the Civil War and a circuit judge after Reconstruction.

Born on May 18, 1817, in Nashville, Tennessee, Wharton was a good student and graduated from Nashville law school at the age of 19. He moved to Clinton, Mississippi, in 1836 to practice law, but returned to Tennessee the following year, where he married Mary Edgar. The couple had nine children.

Around 1839 Wharton and his wife moved to Raymond, Mississippi. In 1856, he was appointed the state’s attorney general and his family moved to Jackson. He remained in that position for eight years, including during most of the Civil War. During the secession crisis of 1861, Wharton also served as a commissioner to Tennessee, tasked with encouraging his native state to secede and join the Confederacy.

After the Civil War, Wharton returned to law practice. In 1882, after Reconstruction, he was selected judge of the Seventh Judicial District. He held that position until 1886. Wharton died on January 28, 1900. He is buried in Greenwood Cemetery in Jackson, Mississippi.

note.p: Charles Clark served as Mississippi’s governor during the last two years of the Civil War. Born in Cincinnati, Ohio, on May 24, 1811, Clark later moved to Mississippi, where he became a lawyer and a state representative in the late 1830s. After successfully representing a Mississippi settler in a land dispute with members of the Choctaw Nation in the early 1840s, Clark received a large tract of land near Beulah, Mississippi, as payment. Clark eventually enlarged his property to over five thousand acres, making it one of the largest and most successful plantations in Mississippi. During this time, he married Ann Eliza Darden and between 1840 and 1852 fathered three children.

Clark volunteered for military service during the Mexican-American War in 1846 and raised a company of volunteers that was placed into the 2nd Mississippi Regiment. After its original commander resigned, Clark was elected colonel. Following the war in 1848, he returned to Mississippi resumed an interest in politics. He was selected as a delegate to a state convention in 1851 that debated the matter of secession in the wake of the Compromise of 1850, which had tried to settle a fierce dispute over the fate of slavery in territories gained by the United States from Mexico. Clark attended the convention as a Unionist, opposed to withdrawing from the Union. Developments over the next ten years changed his mind.

Clark won a seat in the Mississippi’s House of Representatives as a Whig, serving from 1856 to 1861. Following Abraham Lincoln’s election as president in 1860, Clark embraced Mississippi’s secession. When the Civil War broke out, Clark received a commission as a brigadier general in the Mississippi Militia. He later entered the Confederate Army and eventually took command of a division. Slightly wounded at the Battle of Shiloh in April 1862, he was more seriously wounded and captured during fighting at Baton Rouge, Louisiana, in August 1862. Clark spent a short time as a prisoner of war before he was paroled by Union forces.

In 1863, Clark ran for governor of Mississippi, in the wake of Confederate defeats at Vicksburg and Jackson. Clark campaigned on continued resistance to the Union and easily won the executive seat. Due to Union campaigns in Mississippi, Clark periodically moved the state government, from Jackson to Macon, then to Columbus, and back to Macon. When Confederate forces in Mississippi surrendered in May 1865, Clark instructed the state legislature to convene for a special session in Jackson. In June 1865, federal troops at Jackson arrested Clark and imprisoned him at Fort Pulaski, Georgia.

Eventually released from federal custody, Clark returned to Bolivar County, Mississippi. He quietly practiced law and served on the University of Mississippi Board of Trustees during Reconstruction. In 1876, Clark received an appointment as chancellor for the fourth judicial district. He died a year later, on December 17, 1877. Clark is buried in a family cemetery at Beulah, Mississippi.
(Wikipedia; David Sansing, “Charles Clark: Twenty-fourth Governor of Mississippi: 1863–1865,” Mississippi History Now; FindaGrave)

The Congress of the Confederate States of America was established by Article 1 of the Confederate States Constitution on March 11, 1861 in Montgomery, Alabama. Operating at the national level of the Confederacy, it was the Legislative Branch of the Confederate States government responsible for making and amending laws. A bicameral body, the Confederate States Congress was divided into the upper house (Senate) and the lower house (House of Representatives). The Confederate States Congress concluded Its final session on March 18, 1865. (Avalon Project-Constitution of the Confederate States; March 11, 1861; Wikipedia)

On February 8, 1861, the Provisional Constitution of the new Confederate States of America established a federal judiciary. The lower court system itself was structured by a Judiciary Act a month later. It mirrored the United States judiciary in most aspects, including authorizing federal courts to handle all cases involving ambassadors and other public ministers, all cases involving maritime law, all cases in which the central government was a party, cases between two states, and any case involving land grant disputes in different states. The Confederate differed from the U.S system in that it disposed of the circuit courts. The district courts took over circuit court responsibilities.

The Confederate government struggled to establish a Supreme Court. The permanent constitution did not detail the structure of such court, and the Confederate Congress continuously debated but never passed legislation to organize the Supreme Court. Similarly, the Confederate constitution ordered the creation of a Court of Claims which never formally went into being. That court was intended to oversee claims against the Confederate government. Confederate officials disagreed over the exact structure of this tribunal and failed to pass the necessary legislation for its creation.

Confederate military courts differed from the established U.S. system. Confederate General Robert E. Lee complained that the old system weakened the army by removing officers from their primary command responsibilities to temporarily oversee court martial proceedings. In response, the Confederate military developed a structure that placed a permanently staffed court for each army corps and geographical department.

Finally, the state court system remained essentially the same in the south during the Civil War. The defeat of the Confederacy, however, did mark significant changes to the state courts. Reconstruction officials in some southern states vacated the courts and restructured them under new constitutions. In other cases, such as Georgia, the state courts remained intact, but their original justices replaced by Republican officials in order for the new state governments to fall in line with Reconstruction principles. (William M. Robinson, Jr., “Legal System of the Confederate States,” The Journal of Southern History, 453–467; Charles E. George, “The Supreme Court of the Confederate States of America,” The Virginia Law Register, 592–599)

gloss.p: Operating at the state level, the Mississippi judiciary was established by Article 6 of the Mississippi Constitution on November 1, 1890. It is one of three branches of the Mississippi state government, along with the executive branch and the legislative branch. The judiciary branch is composed of four tiers of court: limited jurisdiction, general jurisdiction, intermediate appellate, and last resort. (Mississippi Encyclopedia)

gloss.p: Operating at the state level, the Mississippi High Court of Errors and Appeals was created by the 1832 state constitution and was comprised of three popularly-elected justices. It remained the highest appellate court in the state until 1869, when it was replaced by the state Supreme Court. (Mississippi Encyclopedia)

gloss.p: The Cambridge Dictionary defines and imprisoned person as "a person who is kept in prison as a punishment" (Cambridge Dictionary). CWRGM, however, adopts the subject tag "Imprisoned people" to emphasize the personhood of those who have been imprisoned for crimes. This tag recognizes the systemic injustice and dehumanization historically present in the American carceral system wherein many have been falsely convicted and therefore uses the term "imprisoned" to reflect a person's having been placed in prison, while giving primacy to their personhood and not rendering judgement on that person's guilt (Akiba Solomon, "Words We Use," The Marshall Project).

div.p: [note] This is T. J. Wharton's Letter—

My mind has been so impressed with the vast impor-tance of the question you submitted to me in reference to the power of the State Judiciary, in view of the alarm-ing stretch of Military authority, and the consequent danger of subverting the great principality of State Sovereignty—to vindicate which the struggle in which we are now engaged was inaugurated. State Law induced to [promise?] the consideration of the subject.

In the opinion which I submitted last week I endeav-ored to maintain the proposition that there is a class of cases, arising under acts of Congress, in which the State Courts proposed a concurrant jurisdiction with the Confederate Courts. Subsequent reading and reflection—(for Ihave not been able to throw the subject off my mind) have suggested some additional views which I desire to submit. The importance of the topic will furnish the apol-ogy for [?] to it.
In my former opinion, I failed to notion the [?] of our statute regulating the [?] of proceding in the enforcement to the right to the writ of Habeas Corpus.

By the 1st sec of that statute (Sec Code [?] 365) it is enacted "When any person detained in custody, shall by affidavit of himself, or other credible person, or by other evidence, shown probable cause to believe that he is detained in custody with—

—out lawful authority, to any Judge of the High Court of errors & appeals, or Circuit Judge in this State, either in term time, or in vacation, it shall be the duty of such Judge to grant forth-with the writ of Habeas Corpus" &c. The 2d. Sec provides "that the writ ^or Habeas Corpus^ shall extend to all cares of illegal confinement or detention whatsoever, if by which any person's deprived of his libery" &c.

Ihave sought in vain, amongst the reported decision of the High Court of errors and appeals, for an adjudication if the question arising under that statute. But Statutes of similar import have recieved Judicial constructions in other States. Both from the timing of this Statute, and the decisions of other courts upon similar ones, I am clearly of the opinion that when an application for the writ of Habeas Corpus is presented to a Judge in Mississippi—that application should specify the circumstances under which the petitioner was arrested and detained. Or in the words of the statute, it should set forth probable cause to in-duce the belief with the Judge that the party's detained in custody without lawful authority." This fact the Judge is bound Judicially to believe, before he is authorized to order the infer-ance of the unit. That belief is to be an d intelligent opinion found upon facts presented at the time the application is made. No personal knowledge of the Judge of the circum-stances connected with the arrest and imprisonment will await. They [?] appear on the face of the petition. They cannot be looked for or inquired into, [?] the petition.
The fact that "it is indispensable that the party should show—

as against a return upon the writ showing color of authority in the arrest and imprisonment, that he was illegally imprisoned, does not [?] the difficulty. It arises upon the preliminary inquiry which the Judge is compelled to make, before he is authorized to order the writ to issue.

This much proof—viz—what may be sufficient to induce a ra-tional & ajudicial belief in the mind of the Judge—the party must make in support of his right to the writ. What is it that the judge must believe? Why, that the party "is detained without lawful authority." How if he is to have any such be-lief, unless the facts are laid before upon which to act? I do not say that it is requisite that the proof addressed on the application should generate connection in the mind of the Judge; or that it should be of the character or mea-sure which would authorize the discharge of the party or the hearing—after the writ had issued, & the return had been made by the officer having the party in custody. I do say, however, that prima facie ground must of a belief that he is illegally imprisoned or detained must bestated.

The revised statutes of Massachusetts—Ch 111—Sec 3—pro—requires that in all cases of an application for the writ of habeas corpus, the party imprisoned, orsome person him in his behalf, shall present a petition, and if held under legal proof, or color or pictures of legal proof, shall ^annex^annex a copy of the proof under which the respondant claims to hold back^and^ de-tain him, or makeproof by affidavit, that a copy of such a writ or warrant has been applied for and refund. The Supreme Court of that State, in Liens care, if [?] R 285—Ch 2 Shaw

delivering the opinion—said "We were strongly urged to issue the writ, without inquiring into its cause, and to hear an argument upon the petitioners right to order charges, on the return of the writ. This we declined to do, on grounds of principle, and common & well settled practice. Before a writ of habeas Corpus is granted, sufficient probable cause must be shown; but when it appears upon the partys. our showing that there is no sufficient found prima facie for his discharge, the court will not issue the writ." He proceeds to state that such was the established rule and practice at common law. refer to [?] [?] 3 & 3 & Ald. 420—in which the question [?] & was fully discussed & in which it was decided "that whether the writ [was?] claimed at common law or under the Statute, a proper ground ought to be laid before the court, pre-viously to granting the writ. it is not granted as a matter of course, and the court will not grant it when they see that, in the result they must remand the party."

He answers fully the objection that it is a writ of right, and therefore grantable without inquiry; for, if so grantable, he insists that the issuing of it would be a mere [ministerial?], act, & the party applying might go to the clerk, & [sue?] it out, as he may a writ on a claim for land a money. He also argues that he does not, in his ruling, restrain the full & beneficial operation of the writ, so [?] to the protec-tion of [primal?] liberty, for, he says, that the same Court must decide whether the imprisonment complained of is ille-gal; and whether that inquiry is had, in the first instances on the application, or subsequently, on the return of the writ, or partly on this one, and partly on the other, it must depend on the same facts & principles, & be governed by the same rule of law. He refers to another application which he had refund, on the ground that no sufficient couse appeared in the petition for granting the writ and now upon further consid-eration of the question, he repeats, "that when it appears on the partys. own showing in the petition, that if brought before the court, he would not be entitled to a discharge, the Court will not issue the writ.
Ch. J. Marshall, in Walking care, 3 Peters R 201—decided
